page.title: 01MARDEN - A WEALDEN VILLAGE
page.content: Marden is a village of some 2500+ people. Once almost totally dependent on agriculture many of its inhabitants now commute to London and are young married couples living in first-time buyer housing recently built close to the railway station, which is on the main London-Dover line. Most were born outside the area. The farming is predominably arable and Charles Dickens comment on Kent "Apples, cherries, hops and women" largely holds true though cherries are almost extinct. Cereals, especially wheat and barley and increasingly oil seed rape, can be seen. There is current much concern about the effect of EEC legislation in the hop industry. A number of hop gardens have been grubbed and further Oast Houses, the farm buildings used in the drying process converted to luxury homes.
